body: Do we expect dimensions in the loadSpec to reflect the order of dimensions used for aggregation? Given that dimension order matters it might be worthwhile to preserve the order defined at aggregation time, anyone else have an opinion about this?
@jon-wei OK. Will be fixed by #2690
@nishantmonu51 how much difference does it make if we don't sort the list, and instead use the dimension order used for indexing?

@jon-wei I'm a bit confused as to what we are proposing vs. what we are implementing. You mention several time that what you are proposing is not what is being done in the PR you submitted. Wouldn't it make sense to rework those PRs to do what we ultimately want to do?
@jon-wei ah ok, that makes more sense

Is there a way to "un-introspect" a lookup?

If I have lookups which change all the time and I keep needing to update their introspection endpoints, how can I make sure that unused or stale values get garbage collected properly?

@rasahner The `TaskResourceFilter` is the extra one and does access check for a datasource similar to `DatasourceResourceFilter`. It is needed because `TaskStorageQueryAdapter` is injected in the filter to get the task information from taskId, injecting this field may not be possible in `DatasourceResourceFilter` as it is used at nodes where we do not have the injectable.

Yes, it will be good to have this documented, I can do that in a follow up PR.
@fjy rebased
@fjy fixed
üëç

As requested I am sharing our use case. We're using a TSV in S3 for a namespace lookup (at least to start with, we will probably switch over to a JDBC source eventually). We have a single key column, which always corresponds to the same actual dimension in Druid. We have a dozen lookup columns (could grow by a handful, but I'd think no more than 20). And we're starting pretty small now with only about 100K rows, but expect that could grow to several million rows before too long. 

We don't need this updated really frequently. Actually we're still working out our ETLs and so forth to deal with revisions and additions to the lookup data. But I wouldn't expect us to have updates more frequently than hourly, and probably more like daily.

As far as pain points with this arrangement - there is sure plenty of boilerplate in the config. I have an array of a dozen entries in `druid.query.extraction.namespace.lookups` that are identical in all fields except for `namespace` and `valueColumn`. A bit clunky but not so much that I'd complain about it really - I did write a couple of simple scripts that generate the stuff to be placed in config.

I'm more concerned about the overhead when we do update the lookup source. Druid will have to load and parse this (potentially sized) 20 x 3M TSV once per lookup. I haven't done any benchmarking but I have noticed that it can take on the order of 15 seconds to completely load our current 12 x 100K case. Even if it takes a few minutes that is not a gamebreaker (assuming it does not interfere with query performance or produce inconsistent results while in progress). But it certainly seems like it could be a lot more efficient to load and parse the file once instead of 12 or 20 times.

Overall, the configuration and use feels a bit clunky, I think because from the user point of view, we have just one "lookup namespace" - there is a single source, and a single key column. It would feel more natural to define the data source level properties (uri, format, columns) and key column once, along with a list of allowed targetColumns, then use it in dimension specs and filters by referencing just the one single namespace plus a targetColumn. It might start to look like an ingestion spec at that point, with dataSchema- and ioConfig-like sections. 

But honestly I don't know how much of a priority I'd want it to be. Associating a single namespace with a single key column and multiple value columns might well be overfitting to our specific case, and it 's certainly quite usable as it stands. 

(One side note, the ability to include columns in the CSV which are not key or value columns is useful for assembling the data manually - we can include "friendly name" sort of columns that are helpful to people who are filling in or auditing the actual lookup data.)
This is incompatible but the static config is probably going away anyways.

thanks @ryryguy 
The use case you are talking about seems more like a join than a lookup kind of use case. Just FYI when lookups were spec'd out and designed, the intended use case was for small-ish hash joins to the larger data in Druid (like ID to name), not as a full dataset join between two large datasets.

I have tested lookups up to about 1M unique keys, but much beyond that has not been really investigated because it is outside the scope of the use case for lookups.

If you use off-heap storage for the lookups they should still work for large lookups (few millions of keys), but the impact on performance (especially for filtering on lookups) will not be as minimal as the intended use case of tens to a few thousand unique keys.

"Large" data joins are still on the "would like to do some day" level.
@erikdubbelboer thanks, that's good to hear!

Thanks for the info @drcrallen 

To clarify our use case a little bit further, we are using this functionality because the lookup values are not completely stable. We don't want to trigger mass re-ingestion of the primary data whenever someone corrects a typo in an address or the like.

Also, we would only be querying one dimension from the lookup at a time, but we will allow multiple filters selecting against it. (Slowish performance if multiple lookup filters are selected would probably be acceptable, that is not a primary or major use case.)

One trick I suppose we could do if the length of the lookup started causing problems would be to split them into smaller lookups. The key column in the lookup is a campaign id.  (Rows in Druid represent phone calls; campaigns to phone calls are one-to-many.)  In our business entities campaigns are owned by accounts.  All our queries will also filter on a primary account id. So we could make one TSV per account, embedding the account id in the namespace names. That could cut down the maximum length of a lookup dramatically, though at the cost of increased complexity in marshalling and configuring the lookups. 

If we do need to optimize for performance does that seem like a good approach? Or would having larger numbers of smaller lookups run into different problems?
FYI, I'm taking a crack at the kafka extension because the updates to make it lookup friendly are non-trivial

@navis can you describe the use-case for this? Given that this is a pretty core change, we might want to discuss what the benefits of it are vs. the added complexity of dealing with different types of multi-value dimensions.
:+1: after travis

@gianm maybe it would make sense to clarify what the intended current behavior should be, before we set it in stone with this PR. I agree a sorted set makes more sense to me as well, in which case this might be a bug, and not a feature.
maybe @cheddar can clarify his original intent :) ?

I agree with @xvrl that this is a huge core change (and I don't even develop druid) and you should carefully evaluate the tradeoff. 

Regarding @gianm question of how many values a duplicate should count for I think it is helpful to consider that these k/v arrays are a solution to something that can already be solved (although perhaps less efficiently) with a long form dataset.

i.e.

```
T:t1, D1:x, D2:['a', 'b', 'a']
T:t2, D1:y, D2:['a', 'b'] 
```

Could be stored as:

```
T:t1, D1:x, D2:'a'
T:t1, D1:x, D2:'b'
T:t1, D1:x, D2:'a'
T:t2, D1:y, D2:'a'
T:t2, D1:y, D2:'b'
```

(fun fact this is how druid metrics are emitted)

Keeping this in mind. _If_ there arrays are implemented and used in a groupBy they should count as many times as there are values, in the above example groupBy(D2) should count 3 for 'a'

Maybe it would make sense to talk about these two things separately?
- the desire to embed maps in Druid rows, and the proposal here to represent them as one multi-value column containing the keys and one multi-value column containing the values (that would depend on #2541)
- virtual columns, that could make query output nicer for that proposed map impl and possibly other things as well

The question I have for virtual columns is do we need a new concept to do this, or does the new concept make things nicer enough to be worth the fact that more concepts = more things to maintain?

possible alternatives: Could this be done with a DimensionSpec that has its `decorate` set up reads from two underlying columns? A "map" dimension shouldn't be too crazy now that dimensions are getting generalized. Or could this be done with aggregators? I think yes, as aggregators can read any columns they want and output anything they want.

From a users perspective I have these thoughts:

Having a map column type sounds cool. If it was part of an existing column framework that would be super sweet because there would be way less conceptual overhead.

In terms of `virtual columns` having powerful query time derived columns would be very nice as a concept. Right now the closest thing to that in druid are extractionFns but they are limited by only having one input. I would love to have multi input extractions functions.

Ideally I want the SQL behavior: Say I have a column called `page` then I could treat the expression `SUBSTR(`page`, 1, 2)` just like I do any column.

I can filter on it:

``` sql
SELECT * FROM wikipedia WHERE SUBSTR(`page`, 1, 2) = 'xx'
```

I can group on it:

``` sql
SELECT SUBSTR(`page`, 1, 2), COUNT(*) FROM wikipedia GROUP BY 1
```

I can aggregate with it:

``` sql
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT SUBSTR(`page`, 1, 2)) FROM wikipedia
```

I could also do all of the above with a multi column expression like: `CONCAT(page, '-', user)` 

I want to achieve the above functionality preferably using as few different constructs as possible.
So could virtual columns be folded into extractionFns? (and could those get multi-input support and be useable everywhere? - i.e. also in aggregates)

@gianm yes, as commented above, it can be implemented in various ways but cannot be done without some pain for each way. for example, current DimensionSpec cannot access multiple-dimensions. metric cannot exploit bitmaps (yet). merged column takes much more storage with parsing overhead, etc.

@vogievetsky I think it's possible in anyway (filter, extract, map, aggregate) because it acts like a dimension.
This problem was once mentioned in #2085, I think. Can be a bug but we cannot fix because it would possibly make not-expected result with existing segments.

If I'm reading this correctly, the main changes are:
1. Reducing the number of intermediate strings going into garbage by using StringBuilder
2. Enforcing DelegatingInputFormat as the input class

Is that the basics of it?
This is a bit risky because it depends on `org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.lib.input.MultipleInputs#getInputFormatMap` not changing, which is package protected (aka not public).

But given as how that parsing behavior has been around for quite a long time, it is unlikely to change without breaking other stuff.

In general, there are a few transient test failures, usually related to some of the tests which use zookeeper. And usually only appear on massively over-provisioned (or under-powered) systems like the travis-ci OSS free tier. These transient errors haven't been fixed because they are really hard to reproduce reliably.

The test in the master comment is a relatively new test suite but doesn't have any known transient errors.

Could not reproduce, but changed the test around a bit to see if it can be more explicit about the failure. Please give the patch in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2809 a try and see if the tests pass.
